review.title: Reasoning with Probabilistic Logics
review.abstract: The interest in the combination of probability with logics for modeling the world has rapidly increased in the last few years. One of the most effective approaches is the Distribution Semantics which was adopted by many logic programming languages and in Descripion Logics. In this paper, we illustrate the work we have done in this research field by presenting a probabilistic semantics for description logics and reasoning and learning algorithms. In particular, we present in detail the system TRILL P, which computes the probability of queries w.r.t. probabilistic knowledge bases, which has been implemented in Prolog. An extended abstract / full version of a paper accepted to be presented at the Doctoral Consortium of the 30th International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP 2014), July 19-22, Vienna, Austria

sections.text: ar Xiv: 140 5.09 15v3 [cs.AI] 29 JaKEYWORDS: Probabilistic Description Logics, Probabilistic Reasoning, Tableau, Prolog, Semantic Web.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, many researchers have tried to combine best-in-class logic and probabilities for modeling uncertain areas and conducting inferences and learning processes. In the field of Probabilistic Logic Programming (PLP for a short time), many proposals have been presented. An effective and popular approach is the distribution semantics (Sato 1995), which underlies many PLP languages, such as PRISM (Sato 1995; Sato and Kameya 2001), which are able to combine probability theory (Poole 1997), Logic Programs with Annotated Disjunctions (Vennekens et al al al al al al al) and ProbLog (De Raedt et al al al al al al 2007).

sections.heading: 2 Description Logics
sections.text: In this section we recall the expressive description logic ALC (Schmidt-Schauß and Smolka 1991). We refer to (Lukasiewicz and Straccia 2008) for a detailed description of SHOIN (D) DL, which is based on OWL DL.Let A, R and I refer to atomic concepts, roles and individuals.

sections.heading: 3 The DISPONTE Semantics
sections.text: The idea of DISPONTE is to link independent Boolean variables to the probabilities of the world in order to obtain a world in which we can derive each formula from a particular axiom.

sections.heading: 4 Querying KBs
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it is a purely reactionary, reactionary, reactionary and reactionary project.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 7 Experiments
sections.text: We conducted several experiments to evaluate the performance of the algorithms we implemented. Here, we report on a comparison between the performance of TRILL, TRILLP and BUNDLE in calculating the query probability. We used four different bases of knowledge of varying complexity: 1) BRCA1 models of breast cancer risk factor; 2) an extract of DBPedia2 ontology derived from Wikipedia; 3) Biopax Level 33 models of metabolic pathways; 4) Vicodi4 contains information about European history.For the tests, we used a version of DBPedia and Biopax KBs without the ABox, a version of BRCA with an ABox containing 1 individuals and a version of Vicodi with an ABox containing 19 individuals. To each KB, we added 50 probabilistic axioms, which we added to each dataset we randomly created.

sections.heading: 8 Open Issues and expected achievement
sections.text: Our work aims to develop fast algorithms for performing conclusions on probable DISPONTE semantics. Section 5 shows that TRILL and TRILLP can calculate the explanations for a query and its probability w.r.t. of a SHOIN (D) or an ALC probabilistic KB. For the future, we plan to improve the performance of both algorithms. We also investigate the problem of increased inference for probable logic programming by eliminating elevated variables. To this end, we are developing the LP2 system, which expands GC-FOVE by introducing two new operators, heterogeneous sum and heterogeneous multiplication. This work will be presented at ICLMaxiP 2014.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper we presented two algorithms TRILL and TRILLP for arguing about DISPONTE KBs written in Prolog. Experiments show that Prolog is a viable language for implementing DL reasoning algorithms and that the performance of the two presented algorithms is comparable to that of a modern rationalist.

sections.heading: 10 Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was started by the Artificial Intelligence Research Group of the Faculty of Technology of the University of Ferrara. I would like to personally thank my colleagues and friends (in alphabetical order) Elena Bellodi, Evelina Lamma and Fabrizio Riguzzi.

BUNDLE (Riguzzi et al. 2013a) is a probabilistic reasoner that computes the probability of queries from probabilistic KBs that follow the DISPONTE semantics.

Similarly to BUNDLE, PRONTO (Klinov 2008) is based on Pellet and performs inference on P-SHIQ(D) KBs in which the probabilistic part contains conditional contraints of the form (D|C)[l, u] that informally mean “generally, if an object belongs to C, then it belongs to D with a probability in the interval [l, u]”.

P-SHIQ(D) (Lukasiewicz 2008) uses probabilistic lexicographic entailment from probabilistic default reasoning and allows both terminological and assertional probabilistic knowledge about instances of concepts and roles.

P-SHIQ(D) is based on Nilsson’s probabilistic logic (Nilsson 1986) in which the probabilistic interpretation Pr defines a probability distribution over the set of interpretations Int instead of a probability distribution over theories.
A different approach is the one of Ricca et al. (2009) that presented OntoDLV, a system for reasoning on logic-based ontology representation language, called OntoDLP.
We are adapting the Generalized Counting First Order Variable Elimination (GC-FOVE) algorithm presented in (Taghipour et al. 2013) to probabilistic logic programming under the distribution semantics.

Along this line, in (Riguzzi et al. 2013b) we presented a learning algorithm, called EDGE, that learns the parameters by taking as input a DL theory and a number of examples that are usually concept assertions divided into positive and negative examples.
Moreover, we are working on extending EDGE in order to learn also the structure of a DISPONTE KB togheter with the parameters by adapting the CELOE algorithm (Lehmann et al. 2011).
